docs.lead_paragraph: In announcing his estimate that the Federal budget deficit this year would fall to $37 billion, its lowest level since 1974, President Clinton acknowledged today that the strong economy and resulting unexpectedly high tax receipts had restored the Government's fiscal health even before the balanced-budget agreement he signed into law this week has had a chance to take effect. But Administration officials and many private economists said the budget deal would be vital to keeping the deficit under control in coming years, when the gap between revenue and spending would otherwise begin widening again. And they said the deficit's steep decline over the last several years was due at least in part to previous deficit-reduction efforts, including tax increases to which President George Bush acceded in 1990 and another set pushed through by Mr. Clinton in 1993.

headline.main: Budget Deal, for Now, Takes Back Seat to the Economy
headline.kicker: CLINTON ON THE ISSUES: THE DEFICIT

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, in announcing estimate that Federal budget deficit this year will fall to $37 billion, acknowledges that unexpectedly high tax receipts resulting from strong economy have restored Government's fiscal health even before new balanced-budget accord has chance to take effect; Administration and many private economists say budget deal will be vital to controlling deficit in future years (M)
